Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing Atmospheric Gravity Waves and their Effects on the Antarctic Ozone Layer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stratospheric ozone is an important greenhouse gas that also protects the planet's surface from destructive solar ultraviolet radiation. Depletion of the ozone layer occurs through a series of chemical reactions in which ozone molecules are destroyed by reacting with halogens (chlorine, bromine, etc.) with some of the halogens originating from man-made halocarbons. These reactions are enhanced with cold temperatures at stratospheric altitudes. Current computer models are capable estimating the magnitude of ozone hole development in the stratosphere over the polar regions, but the models underestimate the amount of stratospheric cooling as compared to measurements made by ground-based remote-sensing LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) instruments. This project seeks to better understand the role of atmospheric gravity waves in the Earth's stratosphere and their potential effects on the Antarctic ozone layer. Accurate forecasts of the Antarctic ozone hole parameters by coupling atmospheric chemistry and climate models are critical for monitoring ozone hole recovery. This, in turn, is important for understanding whether or not the goals of the Montreal protocol are being met.

The high-resolution Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model will be used to account for effects of atmospheric gravity waves that propagate upward in the lower atmosphere and, therefore, affect atmospheric circulation, stratospheric temperature, and consequently behavior of the Antarctic ozone layer. A number of Antarctic ground-based lidar data (from McMurdo, South Pole, Davis, Syowa stations, and past observations at Rothera Station) will be used to validate and examine the WRF modeling results. The enhanced gravity wave parameterization will be used to run "The Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model" (WACCM) to study the stratospheric circulation and temperatures above Antarctica. This research effort is a cost-effective investment that will advance the state of knowledge of lower atmosphere dynamics and improve or correct parameterization of gravity waves and, thereby, improve models of the lower atmosphere. In turn this will improve understanding of how lower atmosphere processes can affect ozone depletion reactions. The award will support an early career female scientist with her first NSF funding, as well as support an undergraduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Antarctica ozone depletion has been a great concern for our society because the ozone layer acts as a shield to absorb the harmful UV rays and protects lives on Earth [e.g., Solomon, 1999]. Coupled chemistry-climate models (CCMs) demonstrated that Antarctic stratospheric ozone variations can influence the tropospheric temperature and winds, and thus it can affect predictions of climate change [Son et al., 2008; Polvani et al., 2011]. Therefore, an accurate prediction of Antarctic ozone is important for predicting both Antarctic ozone recovery and climate change. Although recent predictions of Antarctic ozone layer by CCMs showed the recovery of ozone under IPCC scenarios in the 21st century [Austin et al., 2003; Eyring et al., 2007], they suffer uncertainties because of a long-lasting “cold-pole” problem. A cold-pole problem is a cold bias in the simulated stratospheric temperature over Antarctica existing in most CCMs [McLandress et al., 2012]. The stratospheric temperature affects the formation of polar stratospheric clouds (PSCs) that is a critical element for ozone depletion, thus the “cold-pole” problem hinders the accurate prediction of ozone formation and concentration. It is urgent to solve this “cold-pole” problem and lead to more realistic predictions [Austin et al., 2003; Erying et al., 2007].

We have combined a high-resolution model and general circulation model to study impacts of gravity waves to cold-pole problem. Gravity waves resolved by a high-resolution model show hemispheric differences and larger gravity wave activities in the Southern Hemisphere (SH). To test the impacts of hemispheric differences of gravity waves, orographic gravity waves in the SH are increased in a general circulation model. This modification resulted in ~12 K warmer temperature in the SH stratosphere, which improves cold pole problem. However, these adjustments caused temperature in the SH mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region to be changed up to ~28 K. To improve the MLT temperature, non-orographic gravity waves are reduced along with the same stratospheric gravity wave modification. The reason that non-orographic gravity waves are modified is that a climate model seemed to overestimate non-orographic gravity waves compared to a high-resolution model. By modifying non-orographic gravity waves, MLT temperature changes are reduced from ~28 K to ~20 K. Therefore, our study shows that SH stratospheric temperature in climate simulations can be improved by adjusting both orographic and non-orographic gravity wave parametrization based on gravity wave variations that are simulated by a high-resolution models (validated with observations). Further work is necessary to estimate how much modifications are necessary for better climate simulations.

Furthermore, one of our science goal is to examine if responses of gravity waves to climate change are significant enough for us to observe or simulate. Previous work have shown small changes in gravity waves in the low-latitudes and this work focuses on the high-latitude region over Antarctica. Our analysis showed no statistical significant changes of amplitudes of gravity waves and momentum fluxes over 40 years of simulations. Although no significant responses of gravity waves to climate changes are found, we have found the following two interesting variations of gravity waves over Antarctica: (1) Intra-seasonal variations of gravity waves (30-70 days variations) and their potential connection to Madden Julian oscillation (MJO), and (2) ~11 year solar cycle in gravity waves over Antarctica from both lidar and satellite observations and a high-resolution model. This project supported two students and one early career female scientist.
